author: Shiv Sahay Singh Soumya Das
text:
Emphasising that there can be “no democracy in which dissent, debate or dialogue is undermined,” eminent poet and literary critic Ashok Vajpeyi said politics in India has been “reduced to managerial skills with the sole aim to remain in power.”

“All politics has been reduced to managerial strategies on how to manage to remain in power. Against the managerial corporate kind of design to remain in power, there has to be a civic politics of freedom equality and justice,” Mr. Vajpeyi said during the inaugural session of the Kolkata Literature Festival here on Thursday.

Speaking at a session on “Intolerance in tolerant India,” cultural historian and political scientist Tridip Surhud said amid growing debates, crucial issues such as poverty have been ignored,” Mr. Surhud said.

Mr. Vajpeyi said core issues are “being made out to be invisible because now smart cities are being made visible”.Delving on intolerance, the Sahitya Akademi awardee, who was among the first to return the award, said people who echoed similar views like his never said the country was intolerant but “forces of intolerance are being given certain attention”.

On discrimination

Both at the KLF and at another conference of academicians held here, the suicide of Dalit research scholar Rohith Vemula at the University of Hyderabad dominated the discourse.

While Mr. Vajpeyi said the core issue of discrimination continues even in academic institutions in the country, former West Bengal Governor M.K. Narayanan at a gathering of academicians raised concerns that considerations of caste, community and religion dictated the nature of events, leading to heightened tension in universities.
title: ‘Politics is only about remaining in power’
